items.title: U.S. sends aircraft carrier to South America in major escalation of military firepower
items.standfirst: The deployment and the quickening pace of U.S. strikes, including one Friday, raised new speculation about how far the Trump administration may go in operations it says are targeted at drug trafficking.
items.content: The deployment and the quickening pace of U.S. strikes, including one Friday, raised new speculation about how far the Trump administration may go in operations it says are targeted at drug trafficking.(Image credit: Evan Vucci)

items.title: US places sanctions on Colombian president over alleged failure to stop cartels
items.standfirst: Treasury accuses Gustavo Petro of ‘allowing drug cartels to flourish’ as president attacks Trump’s ‘oppressive regime’The US treasury department has announced sanctions on Colombian president Gustavo Petro, one of Donald Trump’s harshest international critics.“President Petro has allowed drug cartels to flourish and refused to stop this activity,” treasury secretary Scott Bessent wrote in a post on X. “Today President Trump is taking strong action to protect our nation.” Continue reading...
items.content: Treasury accuses Gustavo Petro of ‘allowing drug cartels to flourish’ as president attacks Trump’s ‘oppressive regime’The US treasury department has announced sanctions on Colombian president Gustavo Petro, one of Donald Trump’s harshest international critics.“President Petro has allowed drug cartels to flourish and refused to stop this activity,” treasury secretary Scott Bessent wrote in a post on X. “Today President Trump is taking strong action to protect our nation.” Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. imposes sanctions on Colombia’s president amid escalating dispute with Trump
items.standfirst: The Trump administration imposed sanctions Friday on Colombian President Gustavo Petro, his family and a member of his government over accusations of involvement in the global drug trade, sharply escalating tensions with the leftist leader of one of the closest U.S. allies in South America.
items.content: The Trump administration imposed sanctions Friday on Colombian President Gustavo Petro, his family and a member of his government over accusations of involvement in the global drug trade, sharply escalating tensions with the leftist leader of one of the closest U.S. allies in South America.

items.content: Washington has accused Gustavo Petro of allowing drug cartels to flourish during his time in office.

items.title: US sanctions Colombia’s President Gustavo Petro, escalating Trump feud
items.standfirst: The sanctions come as Petro and Trump clash over migration, drug policy and US strikes on boats in international water.
items.content: The sanctions come as Petro and Trump clash over migration, drug policy and US strikes on boats in international water.

items.title: Colombia's president defiant after US sanctions over drug trafficking
items.standfirst: Colombia's President Gustavo Petro on Friday responded with defiance to an announcement by the US that he would face sanctions, along with his wife, son and interior minister, for "allowing drug cartels to flourish". The sanctions come amid a growing spat over drug trafficking that has seen the US destroy several vessels off Colombia's coast.
items.content: Colombia's President Gustavo Petro on Friday responded with defiance to an announcement by the US that he would face sanctions, along with his wife, son and interior minister, for "allowing drug cartels to flourish". The sanctions come amid a growing spat over drug trafficking that has seen the US destroy several vessels off Colombia's coast.

ai_summary: The United States is deploying an aircraft carrier to the waters off South America.
This move is a major escalation in the war on drug cartels, according to reports.
The Pentagon is sending over 10,000 sailors and Marines to the region.
The U.S. has increased strikes on suspected drug vessels in the Caribbean.
The deployment follows sanctions against the Colombian president.

clusters.title: Ontario will pull anti-tariff ads after Trump vows to cut off trade talks with Canada
clusters.neutral_headline: Ontario Pulls Anti-Tariff Ad After Trump Ends Trade Talks

items.title: Ontario will pull anti-tariff ads after Trump vows to cut off trade talks with Canada
items.standfirst: President Trump said he's ending trade talks with Canada over an anti-tariff ad campaign by the province of Ontario that uses Ronald Reagan's voice — leading Ontario to pull the ads after this weekend.
items.content: President Trump said he's ending trade talks with Canada over an anti-tariff ad campaign by the province of Ontario that uses Ronald Reagan's voice — leading Ontario to pull the ads after this weekend.

items.title: Canada to pull tariff ad featuring Reagan
items.standfirst: Canada announced it will stop airing an ad featuring former President Reagan criticizing tariffs, after President Trump said he would cut off trade talks over the ad. NBC News’ Kelly O’Donnell reports.
items.content: Canada announced it will stop airing an ad featuring former President Reagan criticizing tariffs, after President Trump said he would cut off trade talks over the ad. NBC News’ Kelly O’Donnell reports.

items.title: Ontario to stop running anti-tariff advert that angered Trump
items.standfirst: The advertisement will be paused from Monday so "trade talks can resume" with the US, Doug Ford says.
items.content: The advertisement will be paused from Monday so "trade talks can resume" with the US, Doug Ford says.

items.title: Ontario pulls anti-tariff Reagan ad after Trump terminated Canada trade talks
items.standfirst: Ontario's leader Doug Ford on Friday said he would pull an anti-tariff ad campaign quoting former US president Ronald Reagan after current President Donald Trump ended trade talks with Canada.
items.content: Ontario's leader Doug Ford on Friday said he would pull an anti-tariff ad campaign quoting former US president Ronald Reagan after current President Donald Trump ended trade talks with Canada.

items.title: US and Canada spar over ad of Reagan denouncing tariffs that led to derailed trade talks
items.standfirst: Ontario premier says he plans to run ad featuring speech that sparked Trump’s ire again during World Series but campaign will end MondayAfter the US suspended all trade negotiations with Canada over a 1987 speech by Ronald Reagan denouncing tariffs that appeared to spark Donald Trump’s ire, the premier of Ontario said he planned to run an ad featuring the speech again during the World Series on Friday.Doug Ford, whose government ran the Reagan ad in US markets this week, first posted on X that the two nations were “stronger together”, while Trump added his own string of social media posts trumpeting the supposed benefits of tariffs. Continue reading...
items.content: Ontario premier says he plans to run ad featuring speech that sparked Trump’s ire again during World Series but campaign will end MondayAfter the US suspended all trade negotiations with Canada over a 1987 speech by Ronald Reagan denouncing tariffs that appeared to spark Donald Trump’s ire, the premier of Ontario said he planned to run an ad featuring the speech again during the World Series on Friday.Doug Ford, whose government ran the Reagan ad in US markets this week, first posted on X that the two nations were “stronger together”, while Trump added his own string of social media posts trumpeting the supposed benefits of tariffs. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump ends trade talks with Canada over ad
items.standfirst: US President Donald #Trump ended trade talks with Canada after an anti-#tariff advertising campaign funded by Ontario, a Canadian province, aired excerpts of a speech by ex-President Ronald Reagan warning against the dangers of #trade wars. The decision comes as a sudden turnaround, as there were hopes the two countries would sign a trade deal by the end of the month.
items.content: US President Donald #Trump ended trade talks with Canada after an anti-#tariff advertising campaign funded by Ontario, a Canadian province, aired excerpts of a speech by ex-President Ronald Reagan warning against the dangers of #trade wars. The decision comes as a sudden turnaround, as there were hopes the two countries would sign a trade deal by the end of the month.

items.title: Trump says all Canada trade talks ‘terminated’ over ad criticising tariffs
items.standfirst: US president accuses Canada of ‘egregious behaviour’ after release of ad featuring Ronald Reagan criticising tariffsUS politics – live updatesDonald Trump has announced an immediate end to “all trade negotiations” with Canada over a television advertisement opposing US tariffs that quoted the former US president Ronald Reagan.The ad, which was paid for by the government of the Canadian province of Ontario, uses excerpts of a 1987 speech where Reagan says “trade barriers hurt every American worker”. Continue reading...
items.content: US president accuses Canada of ‘egregious behaviour’ after release of ad featuring Ronald Reagan criticising tariffsUS politics – live updatesDonald Trump has announced an immediate end to “all trade negotiations” with Canada over a television advertisement opposing US tariffs that quoted the former US president Ronald Reagan.The ad, which was paid for by the government of the Canadian province of Ontario, uses excerpts of a 1987 speech where Reagan says “trade barriers hurt every American worker”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ontario will stop running an ad featuring Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs.
President Trump ended trade talks with Canada over the ad campaign.
The ad was critical of tariffs and featured a Reagan speech.
Ontario's premier said the ad would be paused to resume trade talks.
Trump cited the ad as the reason for ending trade negotiations.

clusters.title: What to Know About Trump’s Demolition of the East Wing
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Administration Demolishes White House East Wing

items.title: What to Know About Trump’s Demolition of the East Wing
items.standfirst: With little fanfare, the Trump administration demolished the East Wing of the White House in order to make space for a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom. President Donald Trump teased the project for months, first announcing his plan to build a $100 million addition back in February. But the Trump…
items.content: With little fanfare, the Trump administration demolished the East Wing of the White House in order to make space for a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom. President Donald Trump teased the project for months, first announcing his plan to build a $100 million addition back in February. But the Trump…

items.title: Where is debris from the White House East Wing demolition being taken?
items.standfirst: A red and gray scrap truck carried remnants of the East Wing about six miles from the White House.
items.content: A red and gray scrap truck carried remnants of the East Wing about six miles from the White House.

items.title: Satellite images show extent of demolition at the White House
items.standfirst: New satellite images show the White House East Wing has been completely demolished in order to make way for President Trump's ballroom.
items.content: New satellite images show the White House East Wing has been completely demolished in order to make way for President Trump's ballroom.

items.title: How Trump's comments on East Wing demolition evolved
items.standfirst: The building has been torn down to make way for the construction a new $250m (£186m) ballroom at the White House.
items.content: The building has been torn down to make way for the construction a new $250m (£186m) ballroom at the White House.

items.title: White House Staffers Couldn’t Care Less About the East Wing Demolition
items.standfirst: “Not affecting me at all, to be honest,” a White House aide tells WIRED.
items.content: “Not affecting me at all, to be honest,” a White House aide tells WIRED.

ai_summary: The Trump administration demolished the East Wing of the White House.
The demolition is to make space for a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom.
Satellite images show the complete demolition of the East Wing.
White House staffers reportedly are not concerned about the demolition.
The project was first announced in February with a $100 million plan.

items.title: Trump officials to send election observers to California and New Jersey
items.standfirst: Justice department targets two Democratic states holding off-year elections after requests from state RepublicansThe Department of Justice is preparing to send federal election observers to California and New Jersey next month, targeting two Democratic states holding off-year elections following requests from state Republican parties.The department announced it was planning to monitor polling sites in Passaic county, New Jersey, and five counties in southern and central California: Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside and Fresno. The goal, according to the department, is “to ensure transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law”. Continue reading...
items.content: Justice department targets two Democratic states holding off-year elections after requests from state RepublicansThe Department of Justice is preparing to send federal election observers to California and New Jersey next month, targeting two Democratic states holding off-year elections following requests from state Republican parties.The department announced it was planning to monitor polling sites in Passaic county, New Jersey, and five counties in southern and central California: Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside and Fresno. The goal, according to the department, is “to ensure transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law”. Continue reading...

items.title: US Justice Department to send election observers to California, New Jersey
items.standfirst: Republicans in both states have requested the Trump administration monitor for 'irregularities' over Democratic outcry.
items.content: Republicans in both states have requested the Trump administration monitor for 'irregularities' over Democratic outcry.

ai_summary: The Department of Justice will monitor the November midterm elections.
The monitoring will occur in California and New Jersey.
The monitoring was requested by Republican parties in both states.
The goal is to ensure transparency and compliance with federal law.
The Justice Department will send election observers to polling sites.

items.title: Thailand’s Queen Mother Sirikit Dies at 93, Palace Says
Thailand's former queen Sirikit dies aged 93
items.standfirst: The mother of King Vajiralongkorn passed away "peacefully" on Friday night, according to the Thai Royal Household.
items.content: The mother of King Vajiralongkorn passed away "peacefully" on Friday night, according to the Thai Royal Household.

items.title: Thailand mourns as beloved Queen Mother Sirikit dies at 93
items.standfirst: Former Queen Sirikit, mother of Thailand's current King Vajiralongkorn, passed away on Friday night, the palace said.
items.content: Former Queen Sirikit, mother of Thailand's current King Vajiralongkorn, passed away on Friday night, the palace said.

items.title: Thailand’s Queen Mother Sirikit dies at age 93
items.standfirst: Thailand’s Queen Mother Sirikit, who supervised royal projects to help the rural poor, preserve traditional craft-making and protect the environment, died on Friday.
items.content: Thailand’s Queen Mother Sirikit, who supervised royal projects to help the rural poor, preserve traditional craft-making and protect the environment, died on Friday.

ai_summary: Thailand's Queen Mother Sirikit has died at the age of 93.
She was the mother of the current King Vajiralongkorn.
The palace announced her passing on Friday night.
She oversaw royal projects to help the rural poor.
She was involved in preserving traditional crafts and the environment.

clusters.title: Analyzing Trump's pardon of crypto billionaire Changpeng Zhao
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Pardons Founder of Binance, World’s Largest Crypto Exchange

items.title: Analyzing Trump's pardon of crypto billionaire Changpeng Zhao
items.standfirst: President Trump pardoned crypto billionaire Changpeng Zhao this week. The president said the Binance founder was recommended by a lot of people for a pardon. Zhao pleaded guilty to money laundering charges in 2023. He was sentenced the next year and spent four months in jail. Kenneth Vogel, reporter for the New York Times, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: President Trump pardoned crypto billionaire Changpeng Zhao this week. The president said the Binance founder was recommended by a lot of people for a pardon. Zhao pleaded guilty to money laundering charges in 2023. He was sentenced the next year and spent four months in jail. Kenneth Vogel, reporter for the New York Times, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.title: Trump pardons founder of Binance, world’s largest crypto exchange
items.standfirst: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...
items.content: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...

items.title: ‘War on Crypto Is Over’: Donald Trump Pardons Binance Founder CZ
items.standfirst: After serving a federal prison sentence for violating anti-money-laundering laws and US sanctions, former crypto exchange CEO Changpeng Zhao has been pardoned by US president Donald Trump.
items.content: After serving a federal prison sentence for violating anti-money-laundering laws and US sanctions, former crypto exchange CEO Changpeng Zhao has been pardoned by US president Donald Trump.

ai_summary: Donald Trump pardoned Changpeng Zhao, founder of Binance.
Zhao pleaded guilty to money laundering charges in 2023.
He was sentenced to four months in jail.
Trump said Zhao was recommended for a pardon by many people.
The White House stated the "war on crypto is over."

This live blog is closedUkraine wants US to stay involved, says Zelenskyy after meeting western alliesA forthcoming trip by German foreign minister, Johann Wadephul, to China has been cancelled amid growing fears that Beijing’s restriction on semiconductor and rare earth exports could paralyse the country’s car industry.“We are postponing the journey to a later time,” the spokesperson told a regular press briefing on Friday. “The Chinese side was ultimately able to confirm only the appointment with the Chinese foreign minister, and could not confirm any other additional appointments,” a foreign ministry spokesperson said. items.title: Ukraine wants US to stay involved, says Zelenskyy after meeting western allies
items.standfirst: Ukrainian leader joined ‘coalition of the willing’ in London to discuss how to ramp up pressure on RussiaVolodymyr Zelenskyy said Ukraine wants the US to stay involved in efforts to end the war after a meeting of western allies in London that took place without Donald Trump.The Ukrainian leader chose not to overtly lobby for the supply of US Tomahawk cruise missiles at a meeting of more than 20 mainly European leaders from the “coalition of the willing” but instead emphasised the need for the west to work together. Continue reading...

Zelenskyy met with European leaders in London.
The meeting was part of a "coalition of the willing."
Zelenskyy wants the U.S. to remain involved in the war.

clusters.title: Pentagon "crossed this Rubicon" by sending strike group to Latin America, military analyst says
clusters.neutral_headline: Pentagon Deploys Top Aircraft Carrier to Caribbean

items.title: Pentagon "crossed this Rubicon" by sending strike group to Latin America, military analyst says
items.standfirst: The Pentagon said the U.S. is deploying the Navy's newest and most advanced aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald R. Ford, to the Caribbean, along with its strike group. The move comes as Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth posted Friday that the U.S. military carried out its tenth strike at sea on alleged drug vessels. Ret. Army Maj. Mike Lyons, a military analyst, joins CBS News to discuss.
items.content: The Pentagon said the U.S. is deploying the Navy's newest and most advanced aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald R. Ford, to the Caribbean, along with its strike group. The move comes as Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth posted Friday that the U.S. military carried out its tenth strike at sea on alleged drug vessels. Ret. Army Maj. Mike Lyons, a military analyst, joins CBS News to discuss.

items.title: Pentagon deploys top aircraft carrier as Trump militarisation of Caribbean ratchets up
items.standfirst: Use of USS Gerald Ford along with fighter jets comes as president plots strikes against alleged cartels on landThe Pentagon said on Friday that it was deploying the United States’s most advanced aircraft carrier to the Caribbean, a major escalation in the Trump administration’s war against drug cartels that provides the resources to start conducting strikes against targets on the ground.The move will bring the USS Gerald Ford, with dozens of stealth fighter jets and surveillance aircraft, in addition to other warships that accompany the carrier, to the coast of Venezuela as it nears the end of its current deployment in the Mediterranean. Continue reading...
items.content: Use of USS Gerald Ford along with fighter jets comes as president plots strikes against alleged cartels on landThe Pentagon said on Friday that it was deploying the United States’s most advanced aircraft carrier to the Caribbean, a major escalation in the Trump administration’s war against drug cartels that provides the resources to start conducting strikes against targets on the ground.The move will bring the USS Gerald Ford, with dozens of stealth fighter jets and surveillance aircraft, in addition to other warships that accompany the carrier, to the coast of Venezuela as it nears the end of its current deployment in the Mediterranean. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Pentagon is deploying the USS Gerald R. Ford to the Caribbean.
This is the Navy's newest and most advanced aircraft carrier.
The move is an escalation in the war against drug cartels.
The deployment includes fighter jets and other warships.
The U.S. military carried out its tenth strike at sea on drug vessels.

items.title: Cutting cash Isa limit will not boost stock market, MPs warn Rachel Reeves
items.standfirst: Treasury committee says move in November budget could push up mortgage rates insteadCutting the annual cash Isa allowance will not encourage many savers to switch to shares but could push up mortgage costs, MPs have warned the chancellor.Adults can put up to £20,000 a year in a tax-free Isa and spread the money between cash and stock market investments as they choose. In the 2023-24 tax year, 66% of all contributions went into cash savings. Continue reading...

In the 2023-24 tax year, 66% of all contributions went into cash savings. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cutting the cash ISA limit will not boost the stock market.
MPs warn it could push up mortgage costs instead.
Adults can put up to £20,000 a year in a tax-free ISA.
In 2023-24, 66% of contributions went into cash savings.
The Treasury committee issued the warning.

The series of failures lasted for 15 hours and 32 minutes,…
items.content: The outage that hit Amazon Web Services and took out vital services worldwide was the result of a single failure that cascaded from system to system within Amazon’s sprawling network, according to a post-mortem from company engineers. The series of failures lasted for 15 hours and 32 minutes,…

items.title: A single point of failure triggered the Amazon outage affecting millions
items.standfirst: A DNS manager in a single region of Amazon's sprawling network touched off a 16-hour debacle.
items.content: The outage that hit Amazon Web Services and took out vital services worldwide was the result of a single failure that cascaded from system to system within Amazon’s sprawling network, according to a post-mortem from company engineers. The series of failures lasted for 15 hours and 32 minutes, Amazon said. Network intelligence company Ookla said its DownDetector service received more than 17 million reports of disrupted services offered by 3,500 organizations. The three biggest countries where reports originated were the US, the UK, and Germany. Snapchat, AWS, and Roblox were the most reported services affected. Ookla said the event was “among the largest internet outages on record for Downdetector.” It’s always DNS Amazon said the root cause of the outage was a software bug in software running the DynamoDB DNS management system. The system monitors the stability of load balancers by, among other things, periodically creating new DNS configurations for endpoints within the AWS network. A race condition is an error that makes a process dependent on the timing or sequence events that are variable and outside the developers’ control. The result can be unexpected behavior and potentially harmful failures.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A single failure caused the Amazon Web Services outage.
The outage affected vital services worldwide.
The failure cascaded through Amazon's network.
The outage lasted for 15 hours and 32 minutes.
A DNS manager in a single region caused the issue.

clusters.title: Lithuania shuts airports and Belarus border after weather balloon incursion
clusters.neutral_headline: Lithuania Shuts Airports, Closes Belarus Border After Balloon Sightings

items.title: Lithuania shuts airports and Belarus border after weather balloon incursion
items.standfirst: Vilnius and Kaunas airports closed down after balloons drift into country’s airspace for third time this monthLithuania closed its two biggest airports on Friday and shut crossings on its border with Belarus after helium weather balloons drifted into its territory, the third such occurrence in the Baltic state this month.European aviation has repeatedly been thrown into chaos in recent weeks by drone sightings and other air incursions, including at airports in Copenhagen, Munich and the Baltic region. Continue reading...
items.content: Vilnius and Kaunas airports closed down after balloons drift into country’s airspace for third time this monthLithuania closed its two biggest airports on Friday and shut crossings on its border with Belarus after helium weather balloons drifted into its territory, the third such occurrence in the Baltic state this month.European aviation has repeatedly been thrown into chaos in recent weeks by drone sightings and other air incursions, including at airports in Copenhagen, Munich and the Baltic region. Continue reading...

items.title: Lithuania shuts airports, Belarus border crossings after balloon sightings
items.standfirst: Move to close Vilnius, Kaunas airports and border comes after helium balloons drifted into the country's territory.
items.content: Move to close Vilnius, Kaunas airports and border comes after helium balloons drifted into the country's territory.

ai_summary: Lithuania closed its two major airports due to helium weather balloons in its airspace.
This marks the third such incident this month involving balloon incursions.
Border crossings with Belarus were also shut down as a result of the balloon sightings.
European aviation has faced disruptions from drone sightings and other air incursions.
The closures impacted Vilnius and Kaunas airports, the country's largest.
